Sparkle 2 Evo is a casual artistic evolution simulator. Start as a microscopic larva and build your way up the food chain as you evolve based on what you eat.Pros: Graphics are absolutely gorgeous. The game captures the transparency of actual microscope observation, while bathing it in a rainbow of colors. Your stats and appearance changes depending on whether you eat carnivore, herbivore or omnivore matter. You get to confront other microbes in a speed and twirl competition, trying to eat out its weak spots while avoiding its head until it's the only thing left. Music is calm and soothing.Cons: There is no behavior difference between your prey: the exact same creatures simply exists with different colors, making you wonder why a herbivore would eat fish, squids or other animals. You can't die, the extent of risk you face is getting pushed back up one level of depth, or getting a light red glow in the screen if you cannot be pushed up any further. Little replay value: there's a set number of levels with no randomization. There is little complexity over your evolution, and you might accidentally eat matter you wanted to avoid.Verdict: ★★☆☆☆ - Forget itThe game might look and sound exquisite, but there is little more to it. A few hours is all it will take to go through the entire game, do every level and max out your evolution. As it stands, Sparkle 2 Evo doesn't offer enough for me to recommend it.—————————————————————————This was just my opinion.If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, and feel free to check out more of my (purely opinionated) reviews.

												This a great little game, you could say it's one of those hidden gems.Although the playtime isn't that long, the visuals and music is incredible for a game that (most of the time) only costs 1$You play as a small microorganism climbing the evolutionary ladder by eating one of three microelements:-Red which makes your Sparkle (as your species is called) faster and more manouvrable, however at the cost of eating speed.-Blue which makes your sparkle more balanced in the way of movement and eating speed but sadly looking quite uninteresting.-Green which makes your sparkle incredible at eating with the highest eating speed and a skill that makes your mouth about 5x bigger, however it isn't very fast and his turning speed also ins't too great. However the green sparkle is in my opinion the best looking sparkle.As you grow more and more instead of eating stationary microelements you start encountering species, most of which have ways of stopping you eating them often in the form of a slow trap. others take a long time to be fully eaten and until they are they will keep pushing you a level upwards if you touch their head, and others are relatively peaceful but require you to find a way into their body to eat their guts and finally decapitate them.Each stage of evolution your sparkle evolves visually, at first growing longer and developing a type of sac to show you its road to the next level by the size of it, after that it will grow jaws or in the case of the omnivore it will grow even longer, after that evolution truly branches and  every sparkle will go it's own way, i will not spoil this because they look too beautiful to explain.Though the levels are few (there are only 14) there are 2 optional boss battles, The Squid-Worm and the Octury.The Squid-Worm is a large worm that requires you to eat all of his segments before eating his head, not too hard but it looks great and it's a fun way to show yourself how far you've come in your mad dash to become the top species in the sea.The Octury is a humongous octopus that will make you eat all the glowing orbs on it's tentacles before entering it's head and devouring it from the inside out, though -once more not very challenging it's a huge monster that is great to look at in comparison to your little sparkle.This is a great game and if you like Flow or need something relaxing in your library i definitely reccomend you to pick it up, it's very cheap and there are even trading cards to be gained.

												Sparkle 2 Evo is belonging to a series of games with Genesis and Zero, where you're taking the fate of a little sparkle in your hand. Your goal is to make him evolve and reach adulthood. To do that, your little guy can eat microelements, that will determine towards which category he will fall.Indeed, while you don't have any control over the DNA in itself, you can choose to eat only a single kind of element or juggling between them, knowing that when you're leveling up, you can change your form and by doing so use a special ability.You can be a carnivore (by eating red elements) with a sprint as special power, a herbivore, with the possibility of eating elements away from your mouth (for that, you should search green elements) or an omnivore, with a repulsive ability (the blue element will be your best friend).However, through different worlds, you're not alone. You can find octopus, fishes, etc.. that you can eat. They're also belonging to each color: you will find blue, red and green fishes for example. You're generally alone in the world if you choose the casual mode and your goal is to eat one element until none is left. You can choose to continue to explore the rest of the level, which will allow you to level more.But you can also enable the competitive mode, where other sparkles, controlled by the AI, will fight you for dominance. Your only way to win is to ensure that you ate more elements than them. When you win, you can clear the level as in the casual mode.My great regret in that gameplay is that I don't have a real control over DNA. I can't choose the elements I really want. The only way to do it is to eat only the microelements and when you're in competitive mode, you can't really choose to avoid some elements if you don't want the AI to give you time.Also, some enemies tend to swap layers, with a resulting chase being difficult.The graphics are beautiful. You're really in another world, with bright colors. And the soundtrack is really relaxing.  It's fitting to that deep world.Anyway, Sparkle 2 Evo is a game, despite its flaws, that is very entertaining. If you want a total control over your sparkle and have quests, you should orient yourself towards Genesis. If you want just a sparkle without any goal, without any worry about being carnivore/herbivore/omnivore, head for ZERO. However, Evo and Genesis are the best in the series, so, you can purchase it without any problem.

												Sparkle 2 Evo is a casual game. You are an ocean dwelling creature. You eat and grow. There are basically 3 colors of food. Which color you consume the most will determine the type of creature you'll become:- red (carnivore)  => you'll move fast but eat slowly- green (herbivore) => you'll eat fast but move slowly- blue (omnivore) => medium movement speed and medium eating speedAt first red, green and blue blobs just float in the ocean and you eat them to practice the movement of your creature. In later levels, you'll encounter other sea creatures in a variety of shapes but basically you always need to stay away from their head (or they will push you away) until you've eaten what parts of their body you can eat, and then go in for the kill by eating their head. You can play the game in two modes: competitive mode (default) or 'casual mode'. I strongly suggest leaving competitive mode on and only switching it off if you find the game too hard, which isn't very likely. You see, the game gets pretty easy once you figured out how it works. You start at the top layer' of the ocean. You will see radar 'pings' in red, green or blue telling you in which direction there is food of that color. When you don't see any pings anymore, you go down to the next layer and look at your screen for radar pings. Again you hunt and eat until you don't see any pings anymore, then you go down to next layer and so on. If you want, you can focus (more) on one type of food to become your preferred creature type (carnivore, herbivore or omnivore) but in my opinion that is something better left for casual mode because in competitive mode, it's better to just eat everything you find.The graphics are very nice. The music is very subtle and fitting. The Steam Achievements are easy to complete (you'll most likely complete them before you complete the game, unless you happened to miss something). It's a nice game to play for a few hours but don't expect something it's not. Don't expect a twitchy action game or a puzzle-like game that will challenge you for dozens of hours. If the game looks like something you might enjoy, I recommend giving it a go, especially if it's on sale.

												Sparkle 2 Evo... Just a Flow clone?Many people say and think this is a Flow clone, I personally have never played Flow, nor have I watched videos so that will not be influencing this review.Sparkle 2 Evo is about a three hour long game, where you control a microorganism where your goal is to eat to evolve. What you evolve into depends on WHAT you eat, so eating red makes you a carnivore, blue an omnivore, and green an herbivore. Depending on which of the three you become you get special little extra stats, for example the carnivore being the fastest. What you eat ranges from bits of food floating around, to giant squids fifty times your size. Also, each animal you eat requires a specific tactic to beat, for example, using the tactic that’s used on a glass squid wouldn’t work on a skeleton, which makes the latter levels in the game more interesting, and creates some great, well thought out boss battles. There’s also an GenLab, so you can see which of the three traits you use the most, and what your current bonuses are (developers said you can use the lab to change your creature, leading to people believing you're supposed to do it in the GenLab, but they were more getting at the fact that you can change your creature based on what you eat). There’s also a competitive mode where you try to eat more than the opposing AI, fun but not too interesting. A lot of complaints come from this game 'not looking good' or being pixelated, and not having the option to change resolutions. Well, don’t listen to those, because you can adjust resolutions, and it can look damn near perfect on the highest settings. With that having been said, the visuals are beautiful, absolutely just full of vibrant colors, and this may actually be my favorite part of this game. Various corals, and other large debris define the maps, and change depending on the depths of the levels, and location, which I think can be really good at times. The music, well, isn’t amazing. It’s not BAD, but could have used a little more variety.Now for the problems, this game is buggy as heck. One of the more infamous glitches causes you to not be able to progress any further on a boss battle you just spent eight minutes trying to beat, forcing you to restart, and possibly having you do it a third time. Another major bug was a missing species that was required to be killed for an achievement, but recently this has been patched. The last bug I’m going to mention is when the keys stop working. Yes, they completely stop, even when you exit to the main menu and the level reloaded, they still won’t work, forcing you to shut down the game and restart it. And the biggest problem in the game, you can’t be hurt. Did a creature ten times your size just bite you? Well, better throw you up towards the surface then. This completely removes any urgency in the game, making it more boring than it should be (entertaining nonetheless). Pros:beautiful visualscomplex evolution systemgood boss battles (sometimes boring though)Cons:bugs, glitches, etc.controls are… offyour “compass” is confusing at firstcant take damageI would recommend waiting for this game to go on sale (as it often does) if you get it.Score: 5/10Score (if the three mentioned bugs were removed): 7/10Curator page:http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6857919/

												As many others have said--Sparkle is gorgeous.  Unfortunately, the gameplay is one part pac-man and one part screensaver--there's no risk and therefore no challenge; you can't be harmed, you can't die, you can't lose your progress and nothing tries to hunt you down or harrass you.  I understand that there's an element of ideology here, and I respect the movement toward peaceful gameplay (like the freeware Floating Point); but that model isn't well-matched to a game ostensibly about about predation and survival.The idea of branching choice-based evolution--which could have been outstandingly interesting--seems to have been implemented as a hard three-path trinary without significant middle ground between paths.  From what I can tell, if you spend two hours as an exclusive herbivore and switch suddenly to a carnivore diet you don't develop small carnivorous features; you just morph directly into The Carnivore Model for that level of gameplay.I was hoping for a dreamier, more abstract kind of Spore; Sparkle didn't deliver.

												I got this when it was dirt cheap, I had less than one dollar in my steam account, and I still had money left over afterwards, and then it was worth the buy.At 4.99, it is not.It's similar to spore's cell stage, but with none of the complexity of Spore's very simple creature design, all changes are cosmetic and happen automatically.  But the cell stage and this game are different, so i will try and avoid comparing them.  As for the gameplay itself, it's very simple, move the creature around, eat colored pellets.  The colored pellets change how you look.  There is little to no variation between eating the red pellets, the green pellets or the blue pellets besides how they make your creature look.  Sometimes other creatures have red pellets attached to them, but since nothings stopping you from just eating all three, there's no real point in chasing them down unless you're looking for specific designs or trying to follow a specific route, which still, has no effect besides design.  The hitboxes for the environment and for creatures is kind of strange, it always seems bigger than the actual image.I'm not really sure what it's supposed to be.  I would say it's a time waster, but it has a specific amount of levels and isn't engaging enough to make me lsoe track of time.  I would say it's a simple puzzler, but the 'puzzles' only consist of figuring out how to get food from other creatures, and is optional.  I guess it could be called a relaxer, but I never really felt relaxed the entire time, the music is the only bit pointing towards that, and some of the tracks aren't built towards that idea at all.I guess the game looks nice, but the charm is short lived, andthe art style can't hold up an entire game when everything else seems to be lacking.

												As many others have said--Sparkle is gorgeous.  Unfortunately, the gameplay is one part pac-man and one part screensaver--there's no risk and therefore no challenge; you can't be harmed, you can't die, you can't lose your progress and nothing tries to hunt you down or harrass you.  I understand that there's an element of ideology here, and I respect the movement toward peaceful gameplay (like the freeware Floating Point); but that model isn't well-matched to a game ostensibly about about predation and survival.The idea of branching choice-based evolution--which could have been outstandingly interesting--seems to have been implemented as a hard three-path trinary without significant middle ground between paths.  From what I can tell, if you spend two hours as an exclusive herbivore and switch suddenly to a carnivore diet you don't develop small carnivorous features; you just morph directly into The Carnivore Model for that level of gameplay.I was hoping for a dreamier, more abstract kind of Spore; Sparkle didn't deliver.

												SHORT VERSIONPick it up for five euros and have a game that you can whip out for 20-30 minute sessions whenever you want to relax a bit.LONG VERSIONThe art is gorgeous and the beautifully animated sealife is sure to dazzle you at first glance. It comes with a soothing soundtrack to match its visual style. However, the gameplay is repetitive which is both the game's strong and weak point. It doesn't offer anything more beyond what you do in the first level (swim around, eat other organisms, sometimes evolve) but because of that it's  easy to understand and get into. The number of evolutions boil down to three (carnivore, herbivore, omnivore) per developmental stage so there's not much to play around with. You follow the pulsating lights to find food and once you have found it, you feed by simply swimming through it. You win by eating a set amount of food which can get tricky if you are a slowpoke and let other creatures nab your dinner. There are standard, static food such as algae and floating bits of meat but the higher level prey have fun little gimmicks to them. As an example, if you want to consume a baby squid you first need to snip away at its nervous system on the front then the poison glands on the back before it's weakened enough to be gobbled up.The best feature of the game is the inclusion of an optional non-competitive mode which removes the other hungry contestants so you can hunt for food at your own leisure.

												This is a game that is meant to be played "casually".  While the game has multiple z-axis "planes", it is a game largely played on a 2-dimensional field, where you basically just guide your little critter to eat things until you grow up.  There are three "paths" to go down, which you traverse through eating colored blobs of three colors. There are two modes.In the non-competitive mode, you basically just get dumped on a map, and get told to eat everything of one color to go to the next map.  There's essentially no way to lose, but to quit, which I suppose is what makes it "casual", and it's not like games need to be hard to be enjoyable, but there's no particular story, here, to make the world more compelling without it.  There's some "exploration", just to see all the different critters, but once you have seen every level, you've seen everything the game has to offer.In the "competitive mode", you have an AI-controlled critter competing with you for food, where victory is measured in hogging more food than the other guy can get.  While hypothetically, this means challenge and desperately trying to hunt creatures for food faster, regardless of color, in practical effect, you can just stay green and vacuum up everything far faster than your opponent, since the extra bits of food from dividing food pieces all count to your total, and you can consume more food from critters than the game expects to count. In general, I could eat several times more food than the opponent, and never once seemed like I was in trouble unless I completely abandoned attempting to eat for a while.  The big choice in the game about which critter to be is somewhat defeated by the imbalance in the practical use of the different criters.  The "carnivore" red is quick to accelerate, and gets a "dashing" skill to "attack" other creatures.  The "herbivore" green (and I put "herbivore" in quotes because you still hunt and eat other animals, you just want to eat the green ones) has faster eating time (making it so you can eat as fast as you ram through food, rather than skipping over food for a second or so) and has a super AoE suction attack that consumes all food in the area.  The "omnivore" blue (which, somehow, eats a different food entirely from both carnivores and herbivores, rather than just eating both in roughly equal measure,) gets a better turning radius and a defensive sound skill that makes creatures flee from it.Hypothetically, in a game where combat mattered, the difference between an attack skill, a defense skill, and a resource-gathering skill might mean something, but since all you do in this game is eat, the herbivore skill is fantastically useful and makes the game significantly faster and less frustrating, while the omnivore defenseskill is useless since you need to hunt critters, rather than have them flee you, and the carnivore dash attack is pointless since the only enemies that run from you do so across the z-axis, which the dash will not go across.  Ultimately, I recommend this game only on sale for the sheer color and fascination of it.  It's odd and interesting, and worth looking at, and on sale, you can get it dirt cheap enough to justify buying it for aesthetics alone, but there isn't enough actual gameplay to keep you in it.  This is a game you can completely "play out" and feel you've experienced everything it can offer in just a half-dozen hours.

												The game is beautiful and the music is nice, but the gameplay is lacking.  This is a casual game, not meant for people looking for anything deep or innovative, just a little something to waste some time on your phone while waiting for a bus.You evolve your creature by eating either red, green or blue food elements, and the different colors influence how your creature evolves.  These food elements are scattered around the environment and are supposed to evolve you into either a predator, herbivore or omnivore, respectively.  Consuming different amounts of each color produces different visual combinations on your creature, but no change in gameplay.Whether you evolve as a predator, herbavore, or an omnivore, you still guide your creature around eating food elements.  You don't actually become a predator chasing down fast prey.  You never become an herbivore, swimming around to avoid predators.  You never become an omnivore.  No matter what you do, the game is the same: guide your creature around the world eating pellets.  Nothing is hunting you, nothing is trying to fight you off, prey does not illude you, and your competition AI never attacks you, so there is no reason to evolve in any particular direction.Really, the whole challenge is in the controls.  This game was designed for touch screens, and I imagine playing it on a tablet or phone would be incredibly difficult.  I played it with a gamepad, and that made everything too easy.  The difficulty should not stem from the controls.Still, if you're looking for a casual expeience that's beautiful and a challenge on a touchscreen computer, this is all right.  For the rest of us, it's boring and shallow.

The control method and view point change in a very strange way. It feels like a bug. Imagine stepping from our universe and into another where up down, left right and back and forwards suddenly meant different things. Like that. Not fun, and not acceptable. If you want to chill out, turn your brain off and just relax (why are you lookikng for a game to play?) this will do it for you. Just understand it is VERY limited. 												I usually don't do lengthy reviews on games, but this is one that interests me.Sparkle 2 Evo is a game where you eat stuff and grow. That's pretty much it for the concept. There are different things you can eat, which would be herbivore food, carnivore food, and omnivore food. No, they are not called plants, meat, or both.It's a pretty laid back game. In my experience, there really is no way to lose. The opponent AI is pretty dumbed down and moves at a snail's pace. There isn't much else to the game other than: eat, grow, repeat. It really doens't make much of a difference what you choose to eat either.If you choose to be a carnivore, you move faster, but you can only eat one thing at a time. If you choose to be an herbivore, you move significantly slower, but you can eat more things in an instance. I still have yet to figure out what's different about being an omnivore, since it's basically the same as being a carnivore.You basically pick red, blue, or green. Sound familiar?The control scheme is a bit weird. It's functional, but it's weird. You make incredibly wide turns and you'll find yourself running into walls a lot. At least with keyboard/mouse controls. You can pick either keyboard or mouse. I have yet to try out the controller, but I've heard that's what this game is meant for.At points, the game will just seem to drag out. You'll be searching through each layer several times once the level starts to run out of food. You don't win until all the food is eaten (in my experience), and since the opponent AI is slow and often idle, this may take a while. For as far as I've gotten, there really is no sense of urgency.Overall, I wouldn't know what to give this game on a 1-10 scale, but it's relaxing, and it's dirt cheap. If you've ever wanted an expanded version of the first stage in Spore, here it is.

However, Sparkle 2 does address a few of the issues I had with flOw such as the time it took to eat a group of creatures and the lack of a major change in the appearance of the player creature. Even focusing on one color has dramatic changes as the Sparkle starts out as a small larva and eventually develops wings, legs, and assorted appendages.However, the game is not without its flaws, and they aren't in short supply: -Above all else, the game is relatively short (easily beaten with 100% in 2-3 hours) so don't expect a particularly engaging tale -The collision detection is somewhat off and sometimes the passable and impassable barriers were difficult to distinguish. -The beginning decision, carnivore, herbivore, or omnivore is little more than a "Choose your color" decision and overall has little effect on gameplay as your Sparkle can eat all colors regardless of their current forme.Overall, Sparkle 2 Evo is a short but enjoyable title that I recommend if you can get it on sale.
